title: 106_hr200
content: The Act titled "Regional Skills Training Alliances Act of 1999" defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Commerce. Title I of the Act authorizes skill grants. The Regional Skills Training Alliances Act of 1999 authorizes skill grants through the Secretary of Commerce to eligible entities, such as consortia of businesses, labor organizations, government, and educational institutions, to improve job skills for specific industries. The Regional Skills Training Alliances Act of 1999 authorizes skill grants through the Secretary of Commerce to eligible entities, such as consortia of businesses, labor organizations, government, and educational institutions. A majority of representatives in the consortium should be described in paragraph (1)(A), and entities should be located in the same geographic region. Priority is given to small-business concerns, and grants cannot exceed $1,000,000 per fiscal year. SEC. 102. APPLICATION. In states with multiple eligible entities seeking grants, the Governor can solicit proposals and submit applications to the Secretary. If only one entity applies or the Governor doesn't solicit proposals, the Secretary cannot provide grants. The Secretary may not provide a grant under section 101 unless the eligible entity submits an application with required information. SEC. 103. USE OF AMOUNTS. The Secretary may only grant funds to eligible entities if they agree to use the money to enhance job skills needed for employment in their industry. The program allows for assessing training needs, developing skill standards, creating curriculum, acquiring training equipment, and identifying providers. The eligible entity, when granted funds, must enhance job skills for employment in their industry by developing apprenticeship and training programs, providing training for workers, and tracking performance outcomes. Administrative costs can be covered up to 10% of the grant amount. SEC. 104. REQUIREMENT OF MATCHING FUNDS. Eligible entities must provide non-Federal contributions of at least $2 for every $1 of Federal funds, with at least $1 of each $2 coming from participating businesses. SEC. 105. LIMIT ON ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. The Secretary can use up to 5% of funds for administrative costs. SEC. 106. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2002. Planning grants are authorized for States to assist in forming consortia, with a maximum grant amount of $500,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary requires States to submit an application for grants under section 201, including matching funds of at least $1 for every $1 of Federal funds provided. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000.
